GLOSSARY 
Commune/Sangkat  – Commune/Sangkat is the lowest tier of local government in Cambodia. 
Communes are located within the rural districts, and sangkats are located 
within provincial municipalities or the capital, Phnom Penh. 
Khans  – Khans are part of the middle tier of local government comprising districts,
municipalities,  and  khans.  Khans  are  only  located  within  the  capital,
Phnom Penh.
Prakas  – Prakas is a ministerial or inter-ministerial decision aligned with a law or sub-
decree to which it refers and used to implement and clarify specific provisions
in the higher-level legislative documents.
Sub-decree  – A sub-decree is an executive regulation prepared by the ministries, adopted
by the Council of Ministers, and endorsed by the Prime Minister. It clarifies
provisions in a law by describing the functions of government institutions and
may appoint senior government officials in key roles and responsibilities.
Subnational  – There are three tiers of local government in Cambodia that are collectively
administration  referred to as subnational administrations. The highest tier is the capital and
provincial tier and includes the capital (Phnom Penh) and provinces. The
middle tier of local government are districts, municipalities and khans. The
lowest tier are communes and sangkats.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic approach, (ii) a proposed policy-based loan (PBL) for subprogram 1, and (iii) a 
proposed project loan to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Second Decentralized Public Service 
and Financial Management Sector Development Program. 
 
2.  The proposed sector development program (SDP) combines a PBL with an investment 
component to support key reforms in public financial management (PFM) and decentralization. 
The PBL adopts a programmatic approach to strengthen subnational fiscal planning, PFM, and 
public administration. This enables the sequencing of reforms and phased support from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to improve service delivery and bridge the urban–rural divide. The 
programmatic approach builds on ADB’s ongoing first Decentralized Public Service and Financial 
Management Sector Development Program.1 The project component will operationalize the 
National School of Local Administration (NASLA) to provide sustainable capacity development for 
staff of subnational administrations (SNAs).2   
 
II.  THE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  Economic performance. Cambodia has enjoyed strong economic growth between 1995 
and 2018; its gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an average annual rate of 7.7%. Growth has 
been underpinned with effective macroeconomic management, prudent fiscal policy, strong 
performance in domestic revenue mobilization, and low risk of sovereign debt distress.3 Prior to 
the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), the poverty incidence declined from 47.8% in 2007 to 13.5% 
in 2014. These gains are under threat as the economy is now projected to contract by 5.5% in 
2020 due to COVID-19, pushing an additional 1.3 million into either moderate or extreme poverty. 
The government’s fiscal balance will worsen from -5.9% of GDP to -12.8%. Government revenues 
are expected to decline by 30.9% in 2020 as key sectors of the economy grind to a halt.4  
 
4.  Development problem. Service delivery indicators have improved with progress made in 
providing roads, water supply, and sanitation; but access to basic services varies greatly. In 2017, 
only 77% of urban residents and 11% of rural residents had piped water supply. More than 75% 
of urban residents did not have regular solid waste management services. Urbanization has 
heightened the demand for services, which are limited by ineffective institutional coordination. 
Provincial differences also highlight gender disparities—the proportion of women who have never 
attended formal education is higher in rural areas (17.5%) than in urban areas (10.8%).5 
 
5.  Impact of COVID-19. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant decline in key 
sectors of Cambodia’s economy and losses in livelihoods, with the unemployment rate increasing 
from 0.7% to 4.4% (footnote 4). Prior to the onset of COVID-19, more than 70% of Cambodians 
already lived on less than $3 a day, vulnerable to economic and external shocks. Poor and 
vulnerable households are especially at risk from the impact of COVID-19. The government will

need to play a greater role in service delivery to respond to the adverse socioeconomic effects of 
COVID-19 from increased unemployment and reduced remittances for households that are likely 
to jeopardize inclusive and equitable growth. SNA staff will also need to meet additional service 
delivery  needs  to  support  implementation  of  government  response  on  COVID-19,  such  as 
increased social assistance. As demands on SNA staff increase, strengthening SNAs to operate 
in an uncertain environment will be increasingly important.6  
 
6.  Weak  subnational  planning.  The  government  embarked  on  decentralization  and 
deconcentration (D&D) reforms in 2001, establishing a comprehensive subnational legislative 
framework  which  defined  SNAs  as  the  legal  entities  responsible  for  service  delivery, 
responsiveness, and accountability.7 Progress made on service delivery outcomes across SNA 
tiers has been mixed with functions and the assignment of key responsibilities unclear. Provinces 
which are larger, better funded and have more capacity are able to deliver services more 
effectively than districts which are underdeveloped, underfunded and have greater capacity 
needs. The lack of complaints and dispute resolution mechanisms to hold service providers 
accountable for services provided to citizens also limits overall coverage and quality of services.   
 
7.  Ineffective revenue and expenditure management. Revenue mobilization increased 
from 15.2% of GDP in 2014 to 25.9% in 2019 with improvements in tax administration and 
efficiency,8 but remains centralized.9 Availability of resources to meet mandates for service 
delivery remains low. Between 2012 and 2018, district–municipality–khan (DMK) funding as a 
share of the total SNA spending increased from 6.4% to 9.2%.10 The share of commune–sangkat 
funding marginally declined from 27.9% to 25.8%, reflecting priority to the DMK tiers for service 
delivery. Fiscal transfers from the national budget to the capital and provinces accounted for 
64.9% of total SNA spending. Strengthening domestic revenue mobilization at the subnational 
level will be key to service provision and meeting the Sustainable Development Goals.11 
 
8.  Weak  public  administration  and  poorly  skilled  subnational  officials.  Skills 
development of SNA staff is hampered by the absence of a common institutional framework that 
aligns with their duties of service delivery. SNA staff lack regulatory knowledge and technical 
skills.12 Women hold only 18% of permanent positions in the civil service. Existing institutions 
such as the Royal School of Administration serve a narrow cohort of civil servants and are 
operating at full capacity.13 The investment component underpins the overall reform program by 
addressing this skills shortage that constrains effective service delivery at the subnational level.   
 
B.  Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 
 
9.  Government reform agenda. The government has initiated reforms building on the

subnational legislative framework to address local development disparities (footnote 7). Recent 
reforms focus on improving the quality and coverage of services and support the transfer of 
finances and personnel to SNAs. The overarching Rectangular Strategy IV (2018–2023);14 the 
National Strategic Development Plan, 2019–2023;15 the third 3-year implementation plan (IP3-III), 
2018–2020;16 and the Subnational Budget Reform Strategy 2019–202517 serve as the policy 
framework for ADB’s engagement in the sector. The government’s comprehensive approach 
includes: (i) improving the quality of governance; (ii) strengthening human resource management; 
and (iii) better coordination between the national and subnational governments. 
 
10.  ADB’s experience. ADB has provided comprehensive support to D&D reforms since 
2002, including on the subnational legislative framework and operationalizing fiscal transfer 
mechanisms. Between 2002 and 2012, ADB’s engagement focused on strengthening commune 
councils18 and increasing engagement of line ministries in D&D reforms for improved resource 
prioritization for the rural population.19 These engagements were rated as relevant and effective 
in supporting stronger local governance.20 From 2012, under the first DPSFM (footnote 1) an 
efficient system of intergovernmental fiscal relations for improved service delivery was established 
by: (i) reinforcing the regulatory framework; (ii) strengthening institutions; and (iii) defining service 
delivery responsibilities. The  proposed  SDP  is  consistent  with  the  overarching  public  sector 
management reforms,21 and is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 (Table 1)22 and pillar 2 and pillar 
4 of ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2019–2023.23 The programmatic approach for the PBL 
allows  for  sequenced  and  coordinated  interventions  aligned  with  the  national  PFM  reform 
agenda.24 The SDP modality allows for mutual reinforcement. Under subprogram 1 the policy 
actions deepen the legislative framework for improvements in D&D reforms and the project 
ensures sustainability by addressing long-term skills constraints of SNA staff.

11.  Lessons learned. Important lessons have emerged from ADB’s engagement in D&D 
reforms in Cambodia. First, the political, fiscal, and administrative complexities in D&D reforms 
require flexibility in meeting emerging needs and realistic timeframes for implementation. Building 
consensus amongst diverse stakeholders requires significant efforts to maintain momentum for 
reforms.  Second,  while  integration  of  policy-based  and  project  interventions  can  leverage 
commitment for long term policy reforms, more support on implementation is needed.25 The 
proposed SDP reinforces the D&D policy and regulatory framework, while recognizing the need 
for long term support to SNAs for successful implementation of D&D policies.   
 
12.  ADB value addition. ADB’s long-term and comprehensive engagement in Cambodia has 
supported  legal,  policy,  and  institutional  reforms  key  to  furthering  D&D  reforms.  ADB  has 
previously provided TA to support functional mapping of SNA responsibilities and the legal 
framework for intergovernmental fiscal relations.26 ADB also provided TA to pilot decentralization 
of key services such as rural water supply to districts.27 ADB TA resources have supported needs 
analysis for SNA staff and advisory support for the governance structure of NASLA and delivered 
five pilot courses, including a leadership course for women.28 The project under DPSFM II will 
ensure sustainable capacity building and innovations that add value by: (i) ensuring teaching 
quality through peer-to-peer links; (ii) optimizing information technology solutions to improve 
teacher training and student learning; and (iii) tailoring the NASLA curriculum to SNA staff needs. 
 
C.  Sector Development Program Description 
 
13.  The overall program is aligned with the following impact: SNAs deliver public services 
sustainably, effectively, and efficiently to all Cambodians. The overall program will have the 
following outcome: service delivery by SNAs strengthened.29 The first subprogram will develop 
the legislative framework for stronger SNA governance underpinned by an investment component 
for the skills development of SNA staff. The second subprogram will support implementation of 
better service delivery, rendered more important due to the constraints on revenue mobilization 
and expenditures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The project loan will help meet the core 
capacity building needs associated with the overall program.  
 
14.  Reform area 1: Vertical and horizontal coordination for responsive and accountable 
service delivery strengthened. The government improved the links between national and 
subnational policy objectives of strengthened service delivery. First, it approved the Subnational 
Budget Reform Strategy 2019–2025 to outline the next generation of budget reforms. This 
included the expansion of program budgeting and inclusion of SNAs to ensure that local priorities 
are integrated with national objectives. Second, to improve efficiency and coordination, the 
government approved a sub-decree that integrated district-level line ministry offices with district 
administrations. District administrations will have an expanded mandate for service delivery with 
additional  responsibilities  in  education,  rural  development,  and  social  affairs.  Third,  the 
government established internal control functions for improved risk management within the new 
unified district administrations. Fourth, the government approved a sub-decree to establish one-
window services for citizens for faster processing of business licenses and permits. Ombudsman

level. Under subprogram 2, implementation of the Subnational Budget Reform Strategy will 
include strategic budget plans, program budgeting guidelines, audit and ombudsman functions. 
 
15.  Reform  area  2:  Revenue  and  expenditure  management  to  meet  local  needs 
improved. The government boosted the resources available to SNAs to fulfill their service 
delivery duties. First, to meet the increasing development needs of communes and sangkats, the 
government approved the transfer of additional resources from the national budget.30 As a result, 
the overall resource envelope for commune and sangkats has increased with the development 
fund  component  more than  doubled  in  2020  to  address  infrastructure  priorities  and  social 
services, including the expansion of services for women and marginalized groups. Second, to 
improve the management of subnational assets, the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) 
submitted a law on the management and use of state property to the cabinet for approval. The 
proposed law will ensure the transparent management of subnational assets—(i) management of 
state property; (ii) permissible arrangements for rent, sale, and concession of state property; and 
(iii) responsibility for revenue and tax liabilities. Finally, the government approved a 15% share of 
nontax revenues (previously 0%) collected by line ministries and shared with SNAs, to boost their 
revenue base and fund service delivery responsibilities. Under subprogram 2, financial guidelines 
will be established to improve commune, or sangkat fund management and nontax revenue-
sharing arrangements collected from state property strengthened. 
 
16.  Reform  area  3:  Public  administration  skills  and  competencies  of  subnational 
officials enhanced. The government addressed longer-term capacity development needs. First, 
the government approved a sub-decree and guidelines to give SNAs more autonomy in managing 
staff.  Second, the Ministry of Interior (MOI) endorsed prakas and a strategic plan for long-term 
capacity development including delivery of key training programs by type and target group, and 
milestones for improving the development of human resources. Third, under the interim NASLA 
training strategy supported by ADB, five courses were successfully designed and piloted to 
2,087 SNA staff, of which 20% were women. A leadership course for women at the subnational 
level was piloted and jointly delivered with the Ministry of Women’s Affairs. Finally, the National 
Committee for Sub-National Democratic Development (NCDD) approved its gender equality 
policy to strengthen the role and participation of women in service delivery. This included:  
(i) greater representation of women in management; (ii) allocation of resources; and (iii) improved 
services for women and children. Under subprogram 2, guidelines will be adopted to strengthen 
SNAs’ performance management. NASLA will deliver a tailored curriculum and implement the 
gender equality policy at the subnational level. 
 
17.  Project Loan: The project will operationalize NASLA to develop the capacity of SNA staff 
of all ranks and grades for long-term sustainability of D&D reforms. It has three outputs: (i) design, 
construction, and installation of the physical infrastructure of NASLA; (ii) NASLA curriculum 
development to ensure high-quality teaching and training; and (iii) NASLA staff professionalized 
and core operations established. Output 1 includes the design and construction of the NASLA 
complex,  integrating  gender  and  climate-resilient  design  features.31  Output 2  includes:  
(i) diagnostic of the SNA staff competency framework; (ii) pilot of NASLA courses aligned to 
competency standards as agreed with the MOI training department; and (iii) courses delivered 
under the interim training strategy. Output 3 includes: (i) a training needs assessment for NASLA 
staff; (ii) peer-to-peer networks to improve teaching relevance and quality; and (iii) an operations

D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

Climate adaptation is estimated to cost $0.41 million, which includes $0.24 million to climate proof 
NASLA facilities and $0.17 million to support policy reform area 3.2, which mainstreams climate 
concerns into the NASLA curriculum.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  The NCDD-Secretariat (NCDD-S) is the executing agency for the PBL component. The 
NCDD-S, MOI, and MEF are the implementing agencies. For the project component, NASLA is 
the executing and implementing agency. A project steering committee will provide strategic 
guidance to NASLA and aid inter-ministerial coordination. The project management unit (PMU)

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
 
22.  The economic analysis shows that the improved capacity of SNA staff will result in a 
sustained 1.5% productivity gain across all SNA tiers once NASLA is fully operational. The 
estimated economic benefits across the consolidated SNA funds are estimated at $0.30 million in 
2023 and projected to increase to $2.39 million in 2027, remaining at this level until 2045. The 
total accumulated economic benefits are estimated at $65 million for the period 2023–2045. The 
calculated economic internal rate of return for the investment is 13.3%, indicating economic 
viability.  The  fiscal  impact  analysis  confirms  that  the  government  has  adequate  financial 
resources to fulfill its financial obligations for the longer-term sustainability of NASLA.34 
 
B.  Governance 
 
23.  The  financial  management  assessment  was  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
guidelines  and  identified  financial  management  risks  in  staffing,  internal  audit  and  control, 
information systems, and financial reporting. The project financial management risk was assessed 
as substantial due to the limited experience of NASLA in working with development-partner-
funded projects. A PMU will be set up to mitigate financial management and procurement risks. 
Value for money was achieved through contract packaging, and the selection of the procurement 
and bidding method as part of the strategic procurement planning exercise. The MOI will recruit 
qualified financial management and procurement specialists into the PMU with seconded MOI 
Department of Training staff. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained to and discussed with the government, the NCDD, MOI, MEF, and NASLA. The specific 
policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 33). 
 
C.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
24.  Despite progress in reducing poverty, 90% of the poor live in rural areas and their access 
to basic services varies greatly.35 A high maternal mortality ratio—161 maternal deaths per 
100,000 live births—indicates that the quality and coverage of basic health care is insufficient. 
Only 63% of the population has access to lower secondary education. The proposed SDP targets 
improvements in service delivery to local populations. It is categorized as effective gender 
mainstreaming. The gender action plan includes: (i) the integration of gender and disability 
considerations into the design and construction of NASLA; (ii) a curriculum that is inclusive and 
free of gender bias; (iii) a target of 30% of female staff to receive management training; and  
(iv) gender-sensitive training for Ombudsman offices.36

D.  Safeguards 
 
25.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the safeguard categories 
are as follows. 
 
26.  Environment (category B). Environmental impacts from the construction of NASLA’s 
infrastructure (training center and dormitory) are considered site-specific, minor, and reversible. 
The localized impact from construction activities and traffic can be mitigated through effective site 
practice and management. The project site does not experience flooding. NASLA infrastructure 
design incorporates green building and climate resilience principles.37 An initial environmental 
examination  and  environmental  management  plan  were  completed.  Consultations  with 
stakeholders took place during project preparation and will continue during the detailed design 
and implementation.38 The policy actions are not anticipated to have any environmental impacts. 
 
27.  Involuntary resettlement and indigenous people (category C). ADB’s due diligence 
confirms the absence of any land acquisition and resettlement impact. All civil works are within 
the boundaries of the NASLA complex on fenced-in, state-owned land in the Kouk Roka sangkat 
in Prek Pnoy District of Phnom Penh Municipality. The draft due diligence report was disclosed 
on ADB’s website. The PMU will establish a project-specific grievance redress mechanism to 
record and resolve communities’ concerns. The policy actions will not have any impact on 
involuntary resettlement. Due diligence based on the preliminary design suggests that the project 
will not impact any indigenous peoples as defined in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
29.  The government, NCDD, MOI, MEF, and NASLA have assured ADB that implementation 
of  the  program  shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and 
disbursement as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. Loan proceeds for the 
project component will not be disbursed until the following disbursement conditions under the 
project loan agreement have been met: (i) all NASLA project management staff positions funded 
by the borrower are filled through a competitive selection process in accordance with the terms 
of reference and qualification as provided in the PAM; and (ii) NASLA has established a PMU 
following the requirements set out in the PAM.

metadata.Subject:
The proposed sector development program (SDP) combines a policy-based loan (PBL) with an investment component to support key reforms in public financial management (PFM) and decentralization. The PBL adopts a programmatic approach to strengthen subnational fiscal planning, PFM, and public administration.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated August 2020 is provided for the ADB project 52145-001 in Cambodia.
